news.title: Word of the Day
news.description:
Capital Adequacy Ratio
Capital adequacy ratio shows the ability of a bank to face risks and pay back liabilities.
It is calculated by dividing the bank’s capital by risk-weighted assets (assets weighted on the basis of how much loss they will potentially face in the future).
For example, assets such as debentures and bonds can lose significant value in cases of negative sentiments in the debt market.

news.title: 6 Day Course
news.description:
Day 1: Monday
When investing in the stock markets, seeing ups and downs is normal.
Various terms are used when the markets are red. This week, we’ll discuss some of these terms.
Pullback.
A pullback is a short period of a stock price or markets falling — maybe a few days — after it had risen.
Usually, it is seen as an opportunity to buy. The downward movement is viewed as a temporary negative movement.
Pullback happens from a recent high or peak. A stock or index that is already moving down and continues falling is not said to be a case of a pullback.
Pullbacks are extremely common in the markets.

news.title: Featured Question
news.description:
"Why some companies have very high PE, but still continues to hold the higher PE ratio even though the market sentiment is negative?"
 
Many times, some companies have high PE ratios (price-to-earnings ratio) because investors expect the company to do well in the future.
So they buy more, causing the price to go up while the earnings haven’t increased yet.
Many times, when the market sentiment is negative, investors fear most stocks will perform poorly.
In such cases, they feel comfortable putting their money into stocks that they think are stable and reliable.
Therefore, when most stocks are negative, some stocks can attract a lot of attention and investment from others — causing their share price and PE ratio to go up.
